Kural_Info.Tamil_Text: காணுங்கால் காணேன் தவறாய காணாக்கால்காணேன் தவறல் லவை.
Kural_Info.English_Meaning: When I see my husband, I do not see any faults; but when I do not see him, I do not see anything but faults.

Layered_Composition.Foreground: A split composition, showing a woman's perception of her lover.
Layered_Composition.Midground: On the left, she is in his presence ('காணுங்கால்'). He is bathed in a golden, adoring light, and any potential faults he has are completely invisible. She sees no fault at all ('காணேன் தவறாய').
Layered_Composition.Background: On the right, he is absent ('காணாக்கால்'). She is thinking of him, but now her perception is completely different. Her mind conjures an image of him that is covered in dark, ugly faults. In his absence, she can see nothing BUT his faults ('காணேன் தவறல்லவை').

Art_Direction.Subject_and_Action: The paradoxical nature of a lover's perception: when he is present, she is blind to all his faults; when he is absent, she is blind to all his virtues.
Art_Direction.Symbolic_Motifs: The two conflicting perceptions of the same man are the core of the image. The presence of love's light erases the faults, while its absence allows them to dominate the memory. This shows the subjective and emotional nature of her judgment.
Art_Direction.Lighting_and_Color: The 'presence' scene is warm, golden, and perfect. The 'absence' scene is cold, dark, and filled with the ugly colors of the imagined faults. The contrast is absolute.

Technical_Cues.Camera: A stark diptych that shows the two completely different versions of the lover as perceived by the woman.
Technical_Cues.Resolution: 8K, ultra-realistic, with a strong focus on the woman's different emotional states in each scene.
Technical_Cues.Lighting: Strongly contrasting dual lighting schemes to represent the two states of perception.
